You are restless today. Du bist unruhig heute.

The future. Die Zukunft.

The Bloch-Bauer residence on Elizabethstrasse. HEINRICH a KLAUS, two soldiers in Nazi uniform, stand outside it and start pounding loudly on the front doors. Standing behind them in civilian clothes is the Gestapo agent, FELIX LAND HEINRICH . HEINRICH (CONT’D) Open the door! Offnen Sie die Tir! EXT. LOS ANGELES STREET. DAY. Superimposed caption : LOS ANGELES, 1999 A car drives down a Los Angeles street and passes by a sm knitwear boutique - this little shop looks very European, small and quaint - quite incongruous in the West Hollywoo surroundings.  INT. MARIA'S BOUTIQUE. DAY. The phone is ringing in Maria’s knitwear boutique, as MAR is handing a purple cardigan over to a customer. Maria is elderly, beautiful woman who oozes old world charm and elegance. Behind her chic ensembles and delicate manner however there is a fair amount of steel as well as an anarchic streak. Her customer is LIZBET, another elderly woman of European provenance.
When I saw this one I decided it had your name on it. Lizbet tries on the cardigan.
Purple is definitely your colour. I don’t know why it’s taken you sixty years to discover it. The phone keeps ringing; Maria excuses herself with a smi and answers it.
Hello? Yes, my dear, it is. I see. Yes, of course. Thank you for letting me know. She puts down the receiver. And in her face we see that s has just received some life-changing news. Lizbet notices
Are you alright Maria? And when Maria utters her sister’s name, it is to herself

Luise. EXT. A CEMETERY. DAY. A Jewish cemetery on a sunny afternoon, an oasis of calm against the Los Angeles skyline. People huddled around LUISE’S coffin as Maria makes a short speech. She looks dignified in an unostentatious suit.

My sister and I loved each other but the truth is that we were always competing. If life is a race, then she has beaten me to the finishing line. But if it isa boxing match, then I’m the last one standing. A ripple of laughter from those who knew them both. With spade, Maria throws some earth into the grave. And when s speaks again, it is quietly, looking down at her sister’s coffin.
Either way, we went through a lot together, and I will miss you. Auf wiedersehen, Liebe Schwester.

As the mourners make their way to the waiting limos in th late afternoon sun, Maria is accompanied by BARBARA SCHOENBERG, an old family friend. Barbara is in her sixti an academic who is intelligent and warm.
Thank you for coming, Barbara, to have you here means a lot.
Our families go back a long way. How are you coping?
I’m getting used to losing the people I love. Practice makes perfect, my dear. And that reminds her of a job that needs doing.
Barbara. Your son, the lawyer...
Randy?
Last time I saw him he was wearing braces and reading a Spiderman comic. How is he?
Struggling, I’m afraid. Maria looks at her, uncomprehending.
After law school he worked at a fancy firm for four years, then decided to set out on his own in Pasadena.
So what happened?
It all fell apart. Add those debts to seven years of student loans and things aren’t great.
I’m sorry to hear it. They’ve reached the cars. A chauffeur opens the door for Maria.
Good news is he has an interview coming up with a firm downtown. Something solid.
Well, that sounds promising. The two women kiss and Maria gets into the car.
You need a lawyer?

Some letters I found in my sister's belongings. I need advice from someone I can trust. EXT. A LOS ANGELES ROAD. DAY. RANDY is driving his tired car a little erratically along LA road, obviously late. RANDY is in his thirties, eager, with a rough charm . But there is also something a little chaotic and immature about him, as if he is still searchi for his centre.
Randy has his hands on the steering wheel and is sipping coffee from a paper cup as he rehearses for the upcoming interview.

And I really feel that with a firm like yours..and I really feel, sir, that with a firm of this reputation... His cell phone - very much of the period - rings on the passenger seat next to him. He picks it up, placing the c between his thighs.
Hello?
Randy, do you remember Maria Altmann? She has something she wants to ask you.
Not a good time, Mom, not a good time. I’11 call you later. He switches it off, puts it back, and aims for his cup. B he drops it, pouring steaming coffee on his crotch.

shit!  EXT. BERGEN BROWN SHERMAN OFFICES. DAY. Randy is racing towards the impressive glass and steel building that houses the Bergen Brown Sherman Law Firm. H running late, has to weave his way through impressive you lawyers on their way to work. INT. ELEVATOR, BERGEN BROWN SHERMAN. DAY. And in the elevator of the law firm building, he is still rehearsing under his breath.

I sincerely feel that with a firm of this standing, no, with a firm of this calibre.. There’s a high-powered looking lawyer wearing an impressi suit in the lift - he throws Randy a funny, slightly supercilious look and then spots the coffee stain on the crotch. RANDY. It's coffee. Soya cappuccino.

text: In the impressive glass and steel offices, Randy is now b interviewed by the partners that make up BERGEN, BROWN an SHERMAN, all in their sixties. They sit on one side of th boardroom table and on the other sits Randy, who is delivering his rehearsed spiel with nervy gusto.

With a firm as impressive as this, I would be strongly motivated to deliver my very best. SHERMAN has an open folder before him which contains Rand CV : the name SCHOENBERG in bold letters at the top.
Any relation to the famous composer? Randy is a little put out by the question. One senses he this all the time. But he does his best to cover the instinctive response.
Arnold was my grandfather, sir.
His music demands a certain quality of application but the rewards validate the effort.
A radical.
One of the things I would most look forward to is dealing with.. But he’s interrupted.
And Judge Schoenberg is your father.
Retired now, but yes sir, he is.
Outstanding lineage Mr. Schoenberg.
Yes, sir. He gives up, smiles, just a little defeated. It’s not as he’s not used to living in these shadows.
So what happened in Pasadena? Randy is flummoxed by the question. For a second he flounders, then opts for honesty.
I took a risk and it didn’t pay off. Working for yourself isn’t everything it’s hyped up to be.
So now you’re ready to work with others. And all Randy can muster is a smile. But Sherman decides give him a chance. He closes the file.

Let’s give it a go, Mr. Schoenberg. EXT. THE SCHOENBERGS’ GARDEN. DAY. In the slightly scruffy back garden of the house Randy sh with his wife PAM and baby daughter DORA in the San Ferna Valley, Pam and Randy are drinking champagne. Pam is hold the glasses in one hand, balancing Dora in the other. Ran puts on a mock patrician voice, sending the whole thing u little.
Here’s to Bergen, Brown, Sherman, and being able to tell them apart.
I’m so proud of you. And I was thinking..
Uh-oh. She gives him a playful kick in the shins. He feigns pai
We could get out of here, put a down payment on one of those houses we saw in Brentwood. I mean, not now, but soon.
Oh my God, I’ve just come from the interview and she’s already calling the moving company.
It’s the first time we can start making plans.
What is it you don’t like about this place? The leaking taps, the rogue mice, or the psychotic neighbour?
All of the above. And we could get somewhere with a little room I could turn into a studio.
Sounds pretty good. She kisses him, turns to go into the house.
I’m putting her to bed and then we'll have dinner. Couscous. She turns and behind her back he makes a face - he’s obviously not a fan of couscous.
That’s great. I’m going to run out but I’1l be back by eight, eight thirty at the latest.
Where are you going?
My Mom's been driving me crazy. Some family friend woman. I need to get it out of the way. She kisses him.
Okay. Hurry home. EXT. HOLLYWOOD HILLS STREET. DAY. Randy is driving towards Maria’s house, looking a little stressed as he mutters to himself.
Thanks, Mom. EXT. MARIA’S FRONT YARD. DUSK. In the early evening, Randy pulls up in front of Maria’s little bungalow. He gets out of the car to find her water her plants.
I was expecting you at six. It’s ten past.

My apologies, Mrs. Altmann, it was gridlock on Wilshire. And it’s lovely to see you too. As he shakes her hand the sarcasm can’t help but seep thr his smile. Maria starts to make her way towards the front door; he follows.
You look tired and stressed but you’re not bad looking.
Thank you.
Do you know anything about art restitution?
Not a thing.

Well, it’s never too late to learn. Come in and have some strudel. I made it especially for you. And as they enter the house, Randy throws a quick glance his watch. He really doesn’t have the time for this. INT. MARIA’S LIVING ROOM. DUSK. Randy is walking around Maria’s living room, taking it al in. It’s as if a small part of pre-war Vienna has been transported to the suburbs of L.A. He’s looking at an old family picture on the wall from the 1920s when Maria approaches with a slice of strudel for him.

My sister is the pretty one on the right.  INT. LIVING ROOM, ELIZABETHSTRASSE. DUSK. The photo comes to life: it is the 1920’s and the Bloch- Bauers are posing for the photographer: CHILD MARIA and h sister CHILD LUISE, GUSTAV and THERESE, their parents, FERDINAND and ADELE, their uncle and aunt. As each one is mentioned, we see them in close-up as they prepare to hav their photograph taken.
I’m the moody one in the middle. My parents, my uncle Ferdinand, and my aunt Adele.
Come and sit next to me, Komm, setz dich neben mich, Maria, darling. Maria, Liebling.

Adele did not have children, we were like one big family ; I had two sets of parents. GUSTAV GUSTAV (CONT’D) Try to smile Maria, it’s Versuche wenigstens einmal im good to exercise your facial Jahr zu lacheln Maria, es is muscles at least once a year! eine gute Ubung fiir deine Gesichtsmuskeln! They all laugh and there’s a flash as the photo is taken.
The Bloch-Bauers.

The famous Bloch-Bauers. INT. MARIA’S LIVING ROOM. DUSK. And now they’re sitting and he’s finished the cake, puts plate down. Maria hands him a big bundle of letters, tied with a string. He is polite but it’s not easy, he doesn’t want to be here.
I found these amongst my sister's belongings. I’ve translated them for you on the back. He starts to scan them, notices the date.
From our family lawyer in Vienna, Johann Rinesch. All about our paintings which were stolen by the Nazis.  10
Okay.
A month ago I read in the New York Times that things are changing in Austria.
How are they changing?

They're redrafting the art restitution laws. Reviewing old cases. INT. MARIA'S DINING ROOM. DUSK. The dining room basks in late afternoon light as Maria op the sliding doors to it, and it’s madness - all of her sister’s belongings take up the whole room, books and box piled high on the floor and on the table. Randy follows h into the room.
My sister finally moves in with me. Only problem is she decides to do it when she’s dead.
Well, at least you won’t be having any arguments that way. She gives him a look. He flounders, keeps digging.
What I mean is..you know how house- mates argue, like about leaving dishes in the sink and stuff like that. She gives him nothing. Randy digs some more.
So you won’t be arguing. About dishes. Is what I mean. Coz she’s dead. It's agony. He’s reached the end. No more space to dig.
I’m sorry. That was..it was a joke. Well, it was supposed to be a joke. She holds it for a beat.
I’m glad you went for law and not stand-up comedy.
You’re not alone there.  11 She reaches for a box, opens it, takes out a faded old postcard of the Klimt portrait of Adele, hands it to him.
Here she is - my Aunt Adele, painted by Gustav Klimt.
That’s quite a painting.
It’s magnificent. She was taken off the wall of our home by the Nazis. Since then, she has been hanging in the Belvedere Gallery in Vienna.
And now you want to be reunited.
Wouldn’t that be lovely?
It would make you a rich woman, I’m sure.

And you think that’s what it’s about, do you? Randy is slightly taken aback and admonished. With her ha she indicates the many boxes that lay piled and scattered across the room: a family’s history. She picks up an old - a copy of the famous children’s stories Struwwelpeter - runs her hand across the cover. He notices the book.

I have to do what I can to keep the memories alive. Because people forget, you know. And then, there’s justice. And he catches something in her eyes - the memory of a lo lost past and a long-forgotten wrong. EXT. MARIA’S GARDEN. NIGHT. Under the warm Californian night, Maria and Randy are sit in her garden. Randy is holding the postcard of Adele now Maria is holding the letters.

After the war they returned a couple of paintings to us which paid for my nephew’s education. But we had to sign export permits to relinquish any claims to the five Klimts including that portrait of my aunt.
Export permits?
The Klimts were deemed national treasures so we weren’t allowed to take them out of the country even though they belonged to us. So we signed them over.
Just like that?
We didn’t have the strength to fight, we were just grateful to be alive. All we wanted to do was mourn our dead. And there was another important reason we didn’t contest it.
What was that?
We were told that Adele had left the paintings to the Belvedere in her will.
Had she?

We always thought so. Then I read these letters. And she puts them on the table. Randy picks them up, but again he throws a quick look at his watch. EXT. MARIA’S FRONT YARD. NIGHT. A few minutes later, Maria is walking Randy back to his c When they get there, she decides to give her verdict.
I am sorry to have wasted your time. It was a test and we have both failed. He looks at her, doesn’t know what she means.
I have bored you to tears. Four times you looked at your watch tonight.
I got a new job today. I have a baby that keeps me up at night, a wife I want to make happy, several financial institutions who'd like my feet broken, and a plate of couscous waiting at home.  13
So why would you be interested in ancient history? She takes the letters from his hand.
It's great about the new job. And I hope you succeed in making your wife happy. Enjoy your couscous, my dear. He is about to get into the car, then stops. She doesn’ Something
Struwwelpeter. t understand.
That book you were holding. My grandmother used to read those stories to me. Terrifying. The one with the boy who got swept away by the wind...
Into a terrible adventure. I too, found it frightening. small happens; she returns the letters to him.

Just have a look and tell me if I have a case. That’s all I want from you. INT. THE SCHOENBERGS’ BEDROOM. NIGHT. Randy and Pam’s bedroom, like the rest of their house, is small and too crowded; it’s obvious they’ve outgrown it. Randy is lying in bed next to PAM, looking through the letters.
Read that one to me.

‘11th of April, 1948. Dear Luise Bloch-Bauer,’ - that’s her sister - ‘the Austrian Government has decided to return to you two of the paintings which were unlawfully taken from your family during Nazi occupation.’  14 INT. MARIA’S BUNGALOW. NIGHT. Maria goes from room to room, switching off the lights on one before she goes to bed. As the portrait of Adele is mentioned we hover a little on the postcard of it which M has placed leaning against some books in the dining room.

‘This however comes with the full understanding that they will hold on to the Klimt portrait of your aunt and the other four Klimts which they insist were bequeathed to the gallery in her will, a fact which they claim as incontestible.’ INT. THE SCHOENBERGS’ BEDROOM. NIGHT. And as Randy reads the last sentence, his interest has gr
‘The will itself, I have not seen, despite my persistent attempts to do so. Yours sincerely, Johann Rinesch’. And he puts down the letter, looks over at Pam.
So her lawyer never saw the will?
Nobody saw the will. Can you believe that? Nobody.

Nobody? INT. THE SCHOENBERGS’ LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. In his pyjamas, in amongst Dora’s toys, Randy is on the internet, researching the web page of the ‘Austrian Government, Ministry of Culture: Art Restitution claims.’ as his eyes scan the page we can tell he’s already being drawn in a little. INT. BERGEN BROWN SHERMAN OFFICES. DAY. Randy comes out of his office, into the reception area an sees Maria. He’s holding a bunch of papers. Maria is sitt but stands when he approaches. Randy’s behaviour is a lit furtive, as if he doesn’t want to be seen with Maria.
Everybody here looks like they are about to have nervous breakdowns.

Most of them are. We need to photocopy these.  15 Through a glass partition he notices Sherman looking at h wondering who Maria is. Feeling the pressure, Randy start walk down the corridor to where the photocopier is, with Maria in tow. He is obviously in a hurry, fitting Maria i between pressing work at the office.
I was up till three, I did some research for you.
I’m impressed.

Get someone on the ground in Vienna. For the first time in fifty years, they’ve opened the archives. So you start by trying to find a copy of Adele’s will. They have arrived at the photocopier. He starts to make copies for her.
And then what?
The Austrian Ministry of Culture has set up a committee to review each case individually. You need to fill in an application for them to consider your claim by the end of next month at the latest.
Next month? He hands her a piece of paper - she scans it with her eye
I’ve sent away for one already.
Slow down, you're going too quickly for me. You can explain things to me over lunch. And just then, he sees Sherman again, coming out of a conference room.
Oh, no, no, no, no. I can’t do lunch. I can’t do lunch, Maria. INT. NORM’S DINER. DAY. They’ve had lunch. Randy has placed the photocopied paper the table, amidst the leftovers.
These are three names of the top restitution lawyers in America. (MORE)
They’11 cost you but without them, it’s a non-starter.

All I have is my bungalow, my shop, and a little money I’ve been saving for a trip to Hawaii. I don’t want to start throwing cash at some fancy lawyers. He hands her the photocopies across the table, starts to on his jacket.
I need to go.
Randy, I don’t want to rock your boat.
Well, thank you, how considerate.
But maybe you can help me on the side. Like a hobby. He makes a sign at the waitress for the check.
You can’t do this ‘on the side’ Maria, this is a full time job, this is not a hobby.
You are quite rude, a little uncouth, and completely disinterested in the past.
And you have a talent for making me feel good about myself.
But you have the connection.
The connection?

Your family, Randy. Your grandparents. They were from Vienna. We have the same history. And to this he has no answer. INT. RANDY'S OFFICE. DAY. Back on his computer that afternoon, Randy closes a work and starts looking for info on the actual painting, finds piece about it, and his eyes fall on a sentence about its estimated value.  17 With him we read the words : “estimated value is over a hundred million dollars”. We watch his reaction at this p of information. EXT. LOS ANGELES PARK. DAY. Randy and Pam are having an evening stroll in a local par Randy has DORA, their baby daughter, strapped to him. As Randy talks to her about this change of heart, he tries t appear casual, nonchalant - a performance to keep her on side.
I can help her find the will, get the ball rolling, then hand the whole thing over to someone else.
You mean you’re going to go all the way to Austria?
So all I need to do is get the firm interested.
You sure that’s a good idea? You’ve only just started the job, how do you think they'll react if you run off?
I’m not going to run off, honey, I just want to persuade them to let me go. It’s not a big deal.
Besides, you think the Austrians will make it that easy for you? ‘Here’s the files and a pastry’?
Nothing to lose.
Isn’t there? And her question hovers in the air. INT. SHERMAN’S OFFICE. DAY. Randy sits in Sherman’s impressive office. He’s handed Sherman a folder which Sherman is scanning his eyes over.
I can’t have you in Austria chasing paintings, Randy.
Not just any paintings sir.  18
I know them well. Our daughter went to Vienna and all we got was the lousy fridge-magnets.
I see it as a possible investment for the firm.
Go on.
It’s all in there, sir. There seems to be a move in Austria towards making reparations for the past. And these paintings are priceless. I'd be..we’d be representing Mrs. Altmann.
You really think a painting that ends up as a fridge-magnet will ever leave Austria?
I think it would be a mistake not to take a look. For a second Sherman could go either way.
One week max, I want you back on the 3rd.

Thank you, sir! INT. MARIA’S BOUTIQUE. DAY Early evening and Maria has just received a new shipment sweaters at her small boutique. She is taking them out of containers, placing them carefully onto the shelves. Rand bursts in from the street. She works throughout the scene
Still working.
I’1ll close the shop only when I croak.
I’ve got the green light - I’1l go over, try and find the will. Then we take it from there. She is thrilled.
You are chomping at the bite all of a sudden!  19

The bit, yes. And I’ve got another idea... He puts a copy of an Austrian newspaper, the Wiener Zeitu on the counter where she’s folding the sweaters. Points t article. The sight of the Austrian paper unnerves her.
My mother sent me this. There’s an art restitution conference planned later this month. They’re looking for speakers. I think you should be one of them.
What are you talking about?
Elegant descendant of one of the great Viennese families- the press would love you. It would speed things up, apply pressure.
I love your enthusiasm. After all, I’m not a spring chicken, we need to get moving. But in your haste, there’s been a misunderstanding.
There has? And suddenly her tone changes, a raw nerve has been touch She stops her work, folds up the newspaper and puts it in hands.
I’m not going back to that place. Not now, not ever.
I don’t understand.
They destroyed my family. They killed my friends and forced me to abandon the people and places that I loved.
Over half a century ago.
You think that’s a long time?
We'd only go back for a few days. And now she snaps, shows that steel.  20

Randy, you're not listening! I would rather die than go back there. Not for all the paintings in the world. She suddenly feels she may have over-reacted, pulls back, smiles at him. But she knows she’s made her point.
Anyway, a few days ago you weren’t even interested in the case, now you are all over me like a rash. What happened?

Against my better judgement, I think I like you. And she gives him a shrewd look. He can’t quite fool her. despite his shortcomings, she can’t help liking him back. INT. MARIA'S LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. At home Maria is alone in her living room, sitting in an chair in her dressing-gown, surrounded by all her things. in her face we see that Randy’s suggestion that she shoul return has unleashed a tumult of conflicting emotions. INT. THE SCHOENBERGS’ KITCHEN. NIGHT. Randy is feeding Dora, who is in a high-chair. Pam, who i part-time photographer, has some of her most recent photo spread out on the kitchen table and is going through them It’s obvious that she’s not happy about his decision to g
I’'1l be back before you know it. Four days, a week at most. Depends on the reception I get.
So what’s your plan?
It’s just a hunch, no real plan. She stops what she’s doing.
Are you sure about this? We've waited so long for this. You, me, Dora. It’s everything we've dreamed of. I don’t think we should jeopardise that.
I’m not emigrating to the Congo, I’m going to Austria for a few days, with the firm’s blessing. What do you think?  21 She stands up, walks over to him, gives him a kiss on the forehead.

And she leaves the room. But her words take the wind out his sails and plant some doubt in his mind. INT. MARIA'S LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. Still in her nightie and dressing-gown, Maria walks up to old record-player, picks up a record to play. The record Schubert's Du Bist Die Ruh, sung by her husband, Fritz. H name and picture are on the record cover. Near the record player, there is a photo of them both on their wedding da With the music playing, she walks slowly over to the dini room door, opens it. For a few seconds, she stands in the doorway looking at all of her sister’s belongings. Almost if she is frightened of getting closer. Then, slowly, she moves forwards and starts going through them, picking thi up from time to time to examine them, objects from their shared past: photographs, letters, books in German, toys. whole world. And as she goes through them, a change is happening in her, a realisation. Finally, she picks up th old postcard of Adele. And then, a memory returns -- INT. ADELE’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. 1920S Adele is sitting in front of her mirror, putting the fina touches to her outfit for a night out. Out of the corner her eye she spots Maria, the child, who is peeking throug gap in the door.
I see you Maria. Come closer. Ich sehe dich Maria. Komm her. Maria edges in and comes to stand behind her.
Why don’t you help your aunt Modchtest du deiner Tante put on her favourite helfen, machst du mir die necklace? kette zu? She hangs her diamond and pearl necklace around her neck.
Your little fingers are Deine kleinen Finger sind perfect for the job. gerade richtig dafiir. Maria does as she’s told, mesmerised by her charismatic a and her beautiful necklace.
One day soon you’re going to have to stop being so timid. Life will demand it of you. When the necklace is fastened, 22
Bald wirst du aufhéren miissen, so schiichtern zu sein. Das Leben verlangt viel von uns. she turns around and takes Maria’s face in her hands.
Your only enemy is fear.
Dein einziger Feind ist die Angst. INT. THE SCHOENBERGS’ BEDROOM. NIGHT. 1998 The phone rings in Randy and Pam’s bedroom. They’re sleep Randy wakes, picks it up.
Hello? EXT. MARIA’S GARDEN. NIGHT. Maria is standing under the Los Angeles night in her gard on the wireless phone to him. As she speaks, it takes som courage to form the words.
I know it’s the middle of the night but if I wait until the morning, I might change my mind. She stops for a second, takes a breath.
I've decided to face the ghosts. INT. THE SCHOENBERGS’ BEDROOM. NIGHT. Randy puts the phone down. Pam has woken, is looking at h questioningly.

She’s complicated. INT. MARIA’S BOUTIQUE. DAY Maria attaches a piece of paper to the shop door which re ‘THE SHOP WILL BE CLOSED UNTIL TUESDAY THE 4TH OF APRIL’. as she does it, the doubt has crept in again: is she doin the right thing?  23 EXT. L.A. HIGHWAY / INT. CAR DAY. Pam is driving Maria and Randy to the airport. Maria, dre to the nines for the trip, is in the front seat. Randy is the back.
Your Mom called again this morning. She wants you to visit the Holocaust memorial while you're over there.
I know. She’s asked me seven times.
She said you should do it in honour of her grandparents.
Siegmund and Malvina. She had the most beautiful eyes, like an owl.
I noticed that’s a big suitcase you're bringing along, Maria. You sure you're taking enough stuff?
If I’m going back, I might as well do it in style. Now Pam, darling, would you mind going a little quicker, we'll miss our flight.
It doesn’t leave for another four hours.
I want to buy perfume and cognac in the duty free. Pam and Randy exchange a shared look in the rear-view mir as he pulls a face of mock terror. What is he getting him into?
Maybe you should change lanes.
With pleasure, Mrs. Altmann. And Pam puts her foot down on the pedal and overtakes ano car. Maria’s bossiness is effective.  24
An abstract, nightmare vision - a Jewish woman in a fur c is scrubbing the pavement, surrounded by a jeering, mocki crowd of people. A moment of absolute degradation. And a voice is heard.

We’re about to land in Wir werden gleich in Wien Vienna. Please fasten your landen. Bitte schnallen sie seat-belt. sich an. INT. AUSTRIAN AIRLINES PLANE, ECONOMY CLASS. DAY. It was a nightmare - and the voice wakes Maria up with a sudden start. But it’s only the air steward. Maria looks of the window at Vienna, shimmering in the spring sunshin below them.

I never thought I’d come back. She puts her hand on Randy’s. In that one gesture of phys intimacy, all her fear is obvious. And Randy is a little taken aback by it - he senses the emotional nature of the he’s accepted and this makes him a little nervous. EXT. VIENNA. DAY. Montage of Vienna, a world away from Los Angeles: the par the tree-lined avenues, the Schonbrunn Palace. EXT. VIENNA TAXI. DAY. Randy and Maria in the back of the cab taking them from t airport to the hotel. Maria is staring out of the window.
Some guy from the Ministry has agreed to see me tomorrow. I have a feeling he’s in charge of paper- clips.

Landau walks up to Gustav’ cello and picks it up, examines it closely.  44 LANDAU LANDAU (CONT’D) And a cello. Stradivarius of Und ein cello. Stradivari course. Nothing but the best. natiirlich. Nur das Beste. And Gustav closes his eyes, distraught. Therese can’t bea it; she steps forward. THERESE THERESE (CONT’D) No, please! It is his source Nein, bitte! Es ist of joy. Please! seine Lebensfreude. Bitte! But her words fall on deaf ears.
On a beautiful morning, Randy and Maria make their way to Belvedere to meet Hubertus’ mole and search the archives.
I really think I could have done this on my own Maria.

I wasn't going to miss the fun part. It’s like a James Bond film and you are Sean Connery. And as they approach the main entrance, they are met by A a chic young woman who works behind the scenes at the Belvedere.

Hello, I’m Anna. It’s an honour to meet you. INT. THE BELVEDERE BUNKER - DAY. Anna guides Randy and Maria into the area behind the scen passing through a security barrier with a special ID. The pass many works of art which are in temporary storage.
Technically what we’re doing is not illegal, I can authorise it. But still your discretion will be appreciated, I like my job, I want to keep it.  45
Discretion assured.
We'd never want to get a nice woman like you into trouble, would we Randy?

Everything from the museum records prior to 1972 is held in the same room. But I have to warn you - none of it has been computerised yet. She opens a door which leads to a vast room of archives. INT. BELVEDERE ARCHIVE ROOM. DAY. Standing in the doorway, Randy, Maria and Anna look at th room - hundreds of cabinets which contain thousands of fi
I think you’re going to have a busy day.

Roll up your sleeves, Randy. INT. BELVEDERE ARCHIVE ROOM. DAY. A montage of Randy and Maria over the whole day as they rummage through thousands of files and documents. The clo on the wall indicates the passing hours. INT. BELVEDERE ARCHIVE ROOM. NIGHT. Just before midnight Randy finds the file he’s looking fo

Eureka. He opens it- and sees pages and pages of documents from t 1930s and 40s. He throws it to Maria. She looks down at i in big bold letters on the front of the file it has a nam BLOCH-BAUER. She looks up at Randy, moved and excited.

This is it! INT. HUBERTUS’ STUDY. DAY. The next morning Hubertus is holding photocopies of all t documents. Maria and Randy are with him in his beautiful large study of his flat on the top floor of a Vienna pala the house of an intellectual, cultured man.
Congratulations. Quite a treasure trove of information.  46
Hubertus and I were up all night doing some homework.
I’m happy to see you're getting on so well.
And now we can start putting together a picture of all that happened.
Maria, you are the living link to the past.
Hanging on with my finger-nails!
Tell us what you know.
My aunt Adele died in 1925. INT. ADELE’S BEDROOM, ELIZABETHSTRASSE. NIGHT. 1925 Adele is dead, laid out in her bed with a weeping Ferdina by her side.
Meningitis. She was only forty three years old. My uncle was devastated. He said that a large part of him died with her. INT. HUBERTUS’ STUDY. DAY.
Was there ever talk of a will?
I remember my uncle mentioning that she’d written one.
She had. In 1923, two years before her death.
And now, thanks to your brilliant detective work.. Hubertus picks out of the photocopies a copy of the will, shows it to Maria: Adele’s signature stands out.
Her signature, mein Gott.  47
I’ll translate as accurately as I can. This is the part which interests us. He starts to translate a part of the will to them. HUBERTUS (CONT’D) “IT kindly ask my husband to bequeath...”
In Gustav's study, with Gustav standing by her side, Adel writes her will.
“,.my portrait and the other Klimt paintings after his death to the Belvedere Gallery in Vienna...” And we watch her signing it: Adele Bloch-Bauer.
Adele Bloch-Bauer. INT. HUBERTUS’ STUDY. DAY.
So she did leave them to the gallery after all. Dear me, we’ve come all this way for nothing. Is this what’s known as an anti-climax Randy?

One step at a time. You’re right Maria, she does in fact request for the paintings to go to the Belvedere but the request has a very specific condition attached to it. And he picks up the will again, reads a phrase from it. HUBERTUS (CONT’D) “Nach seinem Tode”.
‘After his death.’
She specifically asks for the painting to be given to the Belvedere after Ferdinand’s death.
Let’s tell the story chronologically. Maria, do you have any idea of what happened to your family’s property after you got away?  48
Not at all. Unlike Lot’s wife, I never looked back.
But maybe now it’s time to know. Randy, why don’t you tell us about the home-work you've been doing.
I don’t care if it’s ten o’clock in the morning. Pour me a stiff drink.
The space is full of the cream of the Nazi hierarchy and various art curators - all of them walking around the hou admiring the art, making notes, cutting deals.
After you escaped Austria Maria, your house became the scene of what can only be described as one of the great Viennese auctions of the day.

Your family’s belongings ended up in the hands of the most powerful criminals of the Nazi elite. INT. HUBERTUS’ STUDY. DAY. This news is affecting Maria, every new piece of informat like a stab in the heart.
All our personal things...
Handed over to whoever took a shine to them. And they had a word for it.

Aryanisation. EXT. ELIZABETHSTRASSE - DAY. Two men in Nazi uniform are carrying a painting out of th house and loading it into the back of a small truck. The painting is not visible, covered in cloth.

Did you know for instance that one of your uncle’s favourite paintings, a Waldmuller portrait of Count Esterhazy as a boy..  49 INT. THE LIVING ROOM, ELIZABETHSTRASSE. DAY. And Maria as a small child is going through her uncle’s s collection, with Ferdinand by her side. They are sitting the sofa and on the wall above them hangs the Waldmuller.

I remember it, it was in the living- room. One of his favourite paintings.. INT. BERGHOF. DAY. And the painting is unveiled in a room near a window thro which we catch a glimpse of snow-capped mountains.

.-ended up decorating the walls of no less a place than the Berghof, Hitler's private residence in the Bavarian Alps. And we see the back of a man whom we suspect is Hitler admiring the new acquisition. INT. VIENNA STATE OPERA. NIGHT. A glittering audience populated by Nazis and their female companions fill the Opera House during a performance of a Wagner opera. On stage, a tenor sings an aria. And in the audience, on one of the balconies, HERMAN GOERING sits ne to his young wife EMMY who is wearing Adele’s necklace an glows with the knowledge that all admiring eyes are on he

Or that your Aunt’s necklace, the same one she wears in the Klimt portrait, came to adorn the neck of Emmy Goering, Herman Goering’s young wife. INT. HUBERTUS’ STUDY. DAY. Maria’s devastation grows as she hears of the fate of her family’s most treasured possessions. She takes a swig of bourbon that Hubertus has poured for her.
I almost wish you hadn’t told me all this.
None of the proceeds of this sale of course trickled through to your family.
Not a shilling.  50 INT. THE ADELE ROOM, ELIZABETHSTRASSE. NIGHT. A man sits in the Adele room, looking up at the portrait admiration as he smokes a cigar: BRUNO GRIMSHITZ.

The Nazis themselves were not that keen on the Klimts - they were, after all, a little too degenerate for their taste. But the paintings caught the eye of someone with a more prescient and refined appreciation of art: Bruno Grimshitz, the Director of the Belvedere Gallery. INT. HUBERTUS’ STUDY. DAY.

Grimshitz. An appropriately named character. INT. THE ADELE ROOM, ELIZABETHSTRASSE. NIGHT. And now we watch the portrait of Adele being taken off th wall in Elizabethstrasse by two men in Nazi uniform with Grimshitz supervising.
The paintings were taken off the walls of your family home and carefully transported to what became their final resting place.
And we watch the portrait of Adele being hung carefully i the Gallery as Grimshitz looks on.

Grimshitz knew a masterpiece when he saw it. And then, out of nowhere, a constantly changing parade of museum visitors through the post-war decades from 1946 to present pass by the painting, many pausing to admire it.

Of course, certain facts had to be altered. Like your Aunt’s name for instance. And her Jewish provenance of course. For a short while after the war she became simply known as.. And a visitor leans in to observe the name of the paintin written on a plaque: WOMAN IN GOLD.  51 INT. HUBERTUS’ STUDY. DAY.
Woman in Gold.
Even her identity was stolen from her.
It was not enough to rob your family and try to destroy it. You had to be eradicated from history.
We were Jewish, after all.
So the paintings reached the Belvedere...
In 1941. Your uncle, if I’m not mistaken Maria died..
At the end of the war, in forty- five.
A whole four years later.
So contrary to the request in Adele’s will they were there well before his death.
He died in that hotel in Zurich alone, having lost everything.
And if I’m not mistaken, he wrote his own will before he died..
He did, yes. INT. HOTEL BEDROOM, ZURICH. DAY. Ferdinand writes a will in his hotel bedroom and we see t two names of his nieces as he pens them: Luise, Maria.

Leaving his entire fortune, or at least the shreds that were left of it, to you and your sister, his only living heirs.  52 INT. HOTEL BEDROOM, ZURICH. NIGHT. Ferdinand sits on the edge of his bed, staring into the p alone, approaching the end of his life.
It was one of the last things he did before he died a few days later. INT. HUBERTUS’ STUDY. DAY.
After the war your sister appointed the lawyer Johann Rinesch to see what he could do. An honest man I think, but slightly ineffectual.
That’s a kind understatement.
He started making inquiries about the will but didn’t get very far.
Eventually, the Belvedere persuaded him to sign the export permits as guarantee that you’d never go after the Klimts.
And from that point on, either through oversight or intent, the manner in which the paintings got to the Belvedere in the first place was concealed.
So for decades the truth was obscured.
Until now.
But even if all this happened, the simple fact is that Adele’s will does ask for them to go there. So we haven’t really got a case.
We've kept the best for last. Randy why don’t you show Maria our trump card? And Randy triumphantly brings out an official looking document form the Bloch-Bauer file.
What’s this?  53
A declaration by your father that Ferdinand paid for the paintings. He was the rightful owner, not Adele.
The paintings weren’t hers to give away. And the magnitude of what they reveal suddenly dawns on h
The will is invalid.
Technically, it’s not even a will. It’s not legally binding. It’s a wish, that’s all.
Adele’s wish.
So now we need to get all this to Rudolf Wran, the head of the restitution committee. Randy punches the air, starts moving around the room, he can’t control his excitement.
Yes! And then your aunt is coming home with us, Maria!
Randy, wait, take a deep breath, sit down, listen. Randy does as he’s told, he sits. HUBERTUS (CONT’D) She is the Mona Lisa of Austria Randy.
I don’t care if she’s Botticelli’s fucking Venus! They haven’t got a leg to stand on. Maria and Hubertus look at each other.

That’s what happens when he gets excited. He starts expanding his vocabulary. INT. THE RESTITUTION COMMITTEE OFFICES. DAY. Randy and Maria are trying to arrange a meeting with RUDO WRAN, the chairman of the Restitution Committee but are n having much luck with his receptionist.  54
The thing is I’ve already left him four messages this morning.
Mr. Wran is very busy you understand.
We realise that but it’s essential that we speak to him.
Why don’t you leave him a message?
My dear girl, we’re going around in circles. Suddenly, at the far end of the room two men walk out of Wran’s office and start to make their way to the main entrance of the building. Maria spots them.
Is that him Randy? Randy looks and starts to move towards him with speed, Ma in tow. The secretary shouts after them.
I think it’s best if you leave a message. Randy and Maria catch up with Wran who is now alone - the other man has left the building. Randy is out of breath.
Mr. Wran? Rudolf Wran? Wran looks apprehensive.
Randy Schoenberg. And this is my client, Mrs. Altmann.
Of course. I am so sorry I haven't had a moment to reply to your calls. Maria decides to play her flattering card.
Please don’t apologise, important men like yourself must be very busy.
There’s quite a bit of new information the restitution committee needs to be aware of before it comes to any sort of decision about the Bloch-Bauer case.  55
Is there indeed? Randy gives Wran the folder.
It’s all in there. I’ve made some observations in the margins.
You've been busy during your stay in Vienna I see.
We didn’t come here to eat cakes.
Mr. Schoenberg, I heard you are the composer’s grandson. Do you know what a fan I am of his work?
Glad to hear it.
I can tell you have very refined taste, Mr. Wran.
The genius of the twelve tone compositional system should not be underestimated.
I couldn’t agree more.
Thank you for your efforts. But we have all the information we need. He places the file back in Randy’s hands.
Now if you’ll excuse me, there is work to be done. Wran is off and Randy is left holding the file.
At least he’s a fan of my grandfather's music.
That fills me with confidence.

head_text.subj: EXT. ACADEMY OF FINE ARTS. DAY

text: In the morning sunlight Randy and Maria approach the Acad On a big sign outside it reads: ART RESTITUTION CONFERENC 1998.  56
So weird to think that Hitler once applied to be an art student here.

I wish they’d accepted him. Who cares if he wasn’t a Picasso? It would have been a lot better if he had spent his life doing tacky paintings. INT. ACADEMY OF FINE ARTS, VIENNA. DAY. The main room is full of descendants of families who had their art looted by the Nazis and also by members of the government and media. The room is buzzing. Before the speakers commence, all the invited guests are having coff Maria, Randy and Hubertus are standing in the middle of t throng. Maria looking resplendent in a pink suit.
They're all here. The woman just coming in the door.. We see ELIZABETH GEHRER being welcomed into the room.
Elizabeth Gehrer. Minister of Culture. And we see Rudolf Wran greeting her with an embrace.
With your new friend Rudolf Wran of the restitution committee.
Our music lover.
Quite a turn-out. They’re putting on a very good show.

head_text.subj: INT. ACADEMY OF FINE ARTS. DAY

text: Everyone is seated and there’s a procession of speakers a the podium and we hear snippets of their speeches. The fi speaker is Elizabeth Gehrer. The whole event is being fil for TV.
Welcome to the Restitution Conference. This is a first step in beginning to make reparation towards those whose art was unlawfully taken away from them.  57

head_text.subj: INT. ACADEMY OF FINE ARTS. DAY

text: And now we watch a montage of elderly refugees and Holoca survivors giving their testimonies on the art that was st from their families. Firstly, a woman of Maria’s age, who speaks in German: ELDERLY REFUGEE LADY ELDERLY REFUGEE LADY (CONT’D) The beautiful mountain Die schéne Berglandschaft landscape hung in the main hing im Wohnzimmer unseres room of our house. It was the Hauses. Es war das Erste, w first thing you saw when you man gesehen hat, wenn man da opened the front door. Haus betrat.

head_text.subj: INT. ACADEMY OF FINE ARTS. DAY

text: We watch Maria’s reaction to these speeches and how they resonate with her. And now, an elderly man with a strong German accent is speaking from the podium.
I will never forget the day that they stormed into our house and took our paintings off the walls. We sat there, not being able to say anything, to do anything.

head_text.subj: INT. ACADEMY OF FINE ARTS. DAY

text: It’s Maria’s turn : she is on the podium and speaking wit quiet confidence - but it is not easy, her voice trembles slightly with emotion.

When people see the portrait of my aunt, they see a masterpiece by one of Austria’s finest artists. When I see it, I see a woman who talked to me about philosophy while I brushed her hair and who told me off for biting my nails. There is a ripple of laughter from the audience at this v particular memory.

A woman who, had she not died young, would have had to escape Austria or die in a camp because she was Jewish. You see, restitution is an interesting word. Of course it means compensation, but it means something else as well. I looked it up in the dictionary. There is some laughter from the audience as she puts on h glasses and reads from a small piece of paper.  58
‘Restitution: the return of something to its original state.’ She puts down the paper, looks at her audience.

I know I can’t be a little girl again but, like so many of my generation, who were forced to flee from this city, I would like to return to my original state. I would like to be re-united with my family. As she speaks these words, quietly and with dignity, she can’t help the emotion leaking through. And we watch how words affect Randy. EXT. ACADEMY OF FINE ARTS. DUSK. The conference is over and people are leaving through the main doors into the cold Vienna evening. Randy and Maria on the steps of the building. As Maria is putting on her coat, they are approached by BERNARD KOHLER, a high-ranki employee of the Belvedere. He hands her his card; she loo at it. Randy is immediately suspicious.
Mrs. Altmann. Bernard Kohler, I work at the Belvedere Gallery.
How can I help you, Mr. Kohler?
If the decision of the committee is in your favour, take the three landscapes. But we implore you, not the portraits.
You have grown attached to them.
We can not imagine Austria without them.
Once the past has been put to right, I would be open to reaching an arrangement with you.
I am delighted to hear it. After all, we are all victims of history, Mrs. Altmann. Randy is incredulous at what he’s hearing.  59
Maria, can I speak to you for a minute?
Now if you’ll excuse me, I have a feeling that my lawyer is getting a trifle nervous.
My phone number is on the card. Please feel free to call me so we can resume the conversation. Kohler smiles, gives a little bow, and walks away. Randy fuming.
I think we should be careful what we say, Maria.
What you mean is you think I should be careful what I say.
Just now, you called me your lawyer. People tend to take advice from their lawyers.

When they ask for it. Now, if you’ve finished lecturing me, I think I’m going to walk back to the hotel. And she walks off. Randy watches her go, shakes his head, irritated. The tensions of the visit are getting to them both. Hubertus approaches him, holding his phone. He has just received a text message. He shows it to Randy.
Bad news: they’ve postponed the announcement of the verdict till Wednesday.
Perfect. Two days after I’m expected back at work. That’s just perfect. (NB — RANDY'S LINE IS COPIED HERE AND BELOW, SO THAT THE

EXT. ACADEMY OF FINE ARTS. DUSK

text: Annoyed by her small altercation with Randy, Maria starts make her way down the steps of the Academy. But halfway d the steps, an elderly aristocratic Austrian man, who is putting his jacket on, talks to her, casually throwing hi words over his shoulder, not looking at her in the eyes.  60

A powerful speech you gave. But when will you let the past be the past? You people never give up, do you? Not everything is about the Holocaust. She reels at this sudden, unexpected burst of anti-Semiti For a second she looks as if she might reply. But then sh decides that this man does not merit an answer. She moves down the steps, and towards the road, her dignity intact.

Perfect. Two days after I’m expected back at work. That’s just perfect. EXT. PHARMACY, VIENNA STREET. NIGHT. Maria is walking through the back-streets of the old town when she suddenly sees a place she recognises - an old pharmacy that doesn’t look as if it’s changed in a hundre years. She stops, looks through the window. She lifts her hand and touches it, as if convincing herself that she’s imagining it. And then, memories come flooding back -- INT. LIVING ROOM ELIZABETHSTRASSE. DAY. 1938. Fritz is on the telephone. Maria is standing by his side. places down the receiver and turns to her. They speak in hurried whispers because they know that Heinrich the guar is in the next room.
My brother has booked the last two tickets on a flight to Cologne. We don’t need passports.
And then what?
From Cologne we make our way to the German-Dutch border. There’s a contact - a farmer. He’s been paid to smuggle us across.
When is the flight to Cologne?
Eight o’clock this evening.
Mein Bruder hat die letzten zwei Flugscheine nach Kéln gebucht. Wir brauchen keine Passe. YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) Und was dann?

Von Kéln aus versuchen wir zur deutsch-hollandischen Grenze zu kommen. Dort gibt’s einen Kontakt - einen Bauern. Er ist bezahlt, uns hiniiber zu schmuggeln. YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) Und wann geht der Flug nach K61n?
Um acht heute Abend.  Maria comes up closer, whispers.
I can’t leave my parents.
It’s our last chance, Maria. 61 YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) Ich kann meine Eltern nicht im Stich lassen.
Es ist unsere letzte Chance, Maria. And she knows he’s right; they’ve run out of options.
But someone has to collect the tickets for us and take us to the airport.
A friend of my father’s owes him a favour.
He will never let us out of his sight.
I have an idea. But first, I have to say goodbye to them.
Aber jemand muss die Flugscheine fiir uns abholen und uns zum Fughafen bringen. YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) Ein Freund von meinem Vater schuldet ihm einen Gefallen.

Er wird uns nie aus den Augen lassen. YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) Ich habe eine Idee. Aber zuerst muss ich ihnen auf Wiedersehen sagen. INT. GUSTAV AND THERESE’S BEDROOM. DAY. That afternoon, Gustav is in bed, coughing. He looks very ill, as if his health is deteriorating rapidly. Therese i sitting by him, reading. The door creaks open and Maria sticks her head in.
Mother..father. YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) Mutter...Vater. They look up at her and smile weakly.
Come here, my darling. Come and sit with us for a while.
The time has come, hasn’t it? And Maria has no answer.
Komm her, meine Schatz. Komm und setz dich einen Moment zu uns.

Es ist Zeit Abschied zu nehmen, stimmt’s?  62 INT. THE ENTRANCE HALLWAY, ELIZABETHSTRASSE. DAY. Maria is putting on her coat and gloves with determinatio oozing out of every pore - she is giving the performance her life. Fritz stands by Maria’s side but lets her do th talking. Heinrich is looking resistant.

You know as well as I do that they won’t let my father into the hospitals because he has committed the crime of being Jewish. So the least you can do is let us go and get him some medication from the pharmacy.

And why do both of you need to go? YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) Sie wissengenau so gut wie ich, dass sie meinem Vater nicht erlauben, ins spital zu gehen, weil er das Verbrechen begangen hat, Jude zu sein. Wir kénnen nur zur Apotheke gehen und ihm Medikamente holen. HEINRICH (CONT’D) Und warum miissen Sie beide gehen? And now Maria turns with real stridency to Heinrich, she becoming a force to be reckoned with.

Oh for God’s sake, if you’re that worried we’re going to run away why don’t you come with us? YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) Ach. Um Himmels Willen, wenn Sie so besorgt sind, dass wir weglaufen, warum kommen Sie nicht mit? Heinrich resigns grudgingly, picks up his coat.
I take you there but we come straight back.

That’s a shame. I was hoping we could all go to the cinema. HEINRICH (CONT’D) Ich bringe Sie hin, aber wir kommen sofort zurtick. YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) Schade. Ich hatte gehofft wir gehen alle zusammen ins Kino . And she throws Fritz a look: this is it. EXT. PHARMACY, VIENNA STREET. DUSK. It is dusk as Maria, Fritz and Heinrich arrive at the pharmacy on a quiet side street. It is the same pharmacy Maria comes across as an older woman. As they approach, Heinrich takes out a pack of cigarettes.
I’m going to smoke a cigarette. Don’t be longer than a minute.

Ich rauche eine Zigarette. Sie haben eine Minute.  63 The relief is evident on Maria’s face. Everything is goin according to plan. YOUNG MARIA YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) One minute, that’s all. Eine Minute. Das reicht. And Maria and Fritz walk in. INT. THE PHARMACY. DUSK. Through the window we can see Heinrich smoking. Maria lea Fritz up to the counter. They are both nervous and the PHARMACIST, a hawk-like man picks up on it. He gives them wary look. Maria clocks the door that leads to the back o the pharmacy. PHARMACIST PHARMACIST (CONT’D) What can I do for you? Was darf es sein? YOUNG MARIA YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) My father has a very high Mein Vater hat sehr hohes fever and a cough. We need Fieber und Husten. Wir something that will help brauchen etwas, das die lower his temperature. Temperatur senkt. PHARMACIST PHARMACIST (CONT’D) Wait here. Warten Sie hier. He makes his way towards the medicine shelves which stand the back of the area behind the counter. Maria takes Frit the hand and they go to the door that leads to the back o the shop. They open it and dart through it. INT. CORRIDOR BEHIND PHARMACY. DUSK. Maria and Fritz rush down a small corridor at the rear of pharmacy towards a door that leads to the back street. Th try and open it but it is locked. They both start to pani they look around for another way out. But there isn’t one Fritz notices a big bunch of keys hanging on the wall. He grabs them and starts trying different keys in the door, looking for the right one. Maria keeps looking over her shoulder. INT. THE PHARMACY. DUSK. The pharmacist turns back towards the counter with the medication in hand. PHARMACIST PHARMACIST (CONT’D) This should do it. Das sollte helfen. But he sees they’ve gone. He looks around the shop, can’t them. Then he notices Heinrich, in his uniform, waiting f them outside. He becomes suspicious.  64 And then he sees the open door that leads to the corridor goes through it, like a dog on the scent of something. INT. THE CORRIDOR BEHIND PHARMACY. DUSK. The pharmacist walks into the corridor and sees Maria and Fritz trying the different keys in the door.
What are you doing?
I’m feeling faint. I need some air. Please open the door.

This is a private area. If you want air, go out the way you came in. PHARMACIST (CONT’D) Was machen Sie da? YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) Ich fiihle mich schwach. Ich brauche etwas Luft. Bitte 6ffnen Sie die Tiir. PHARMACIST (CONT’D) Dies ist ein privater Bereich. Wenn Sie Luft brauchen, gehen Sie dahin, wo Sie hergekommen sind. Fritz is desperately trying the keys in the door.

Put those keys down! You have no business being here! PHARMACIST (CONT’D) Legen Sie diese Schliissel hin! Sie haben hier nichts zu suchen! Maria knows she can’t keep the act going. She tries to ap to his kindness.
Please! Please let us out. We have done nothing wrong. Please help us!
The soldier smoking on the street is with you?
No. Please, quickly, open the door.
I saw you arrive together.

YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) Bitte! Bitte lassen Sie uns raus. Wir haben nichts Unrechtes getan. Bitte helfen Sie uns! PHARMACIST (CONT’D) Der Soldat, der auf der StraBe raucht, gehért zu Ihnen? YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) Nein. Bitte, 6ffnen Sie die Tir, schnell. PHARMACIST (CONT’D) Ich habe Sie zusammen ankommen sehen.

65 And then, he figures it out. PHARMACIST PHARMACIST (CONT’D) Of course, you are Jews. Natiirlich, Sie sind Juden. And he runs back into the shop and starts shouting to Heinrich on the street. PHARMACIST PHARMACIST (CONT’D) They are trying to get away! Die versuchen abzuhauen! EXT. THE PHARMACY. DUSK. Heinrich hears the pharmacist calling him. He throws his cigarette on the pavement and runs into the pharmacy. INT/EXT. THE CORRIDOR BEHIND PHARMACY. DUSK.
