Thank you Dr. Toman. This morning I’m feeling as if I have another fifty years in front of me. Toman looks confused at the private joke between Maria an Randy.

All rise. JUDGE FLORENCE COOPER enters. She is an impressive woman great authority but not intimidating. Maria takes a small handkerchief out of her hand-bag and dabs the chocolate o Randy’s nose. INT. COURTROOM, THE DISTRICT COURT. DAY. The court case. Judge Cooper sits at the bench. Randy and Maria on one side, Gould and Toman on the other. The sess is in full swing.

Your Honour, the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act was passed in 1976, a good thirty eight years after the events in question. It seems to me obvious that the FSIA rulings can not be applied retroactively and I am bewildered that Mrs. Altmann’s counsel has not advised her of this fact. It would have saved her a great deal of inconvenience and an equal amount of false hope. Suddenly, Maria puts her hand up and speaks.

It really isn’t much of an inconvenience. If I wasn’t here, I'd either be at my shop or at home watching ‘Days of Our Lives’. Randy is mortified at her interruption, the others can’t quite believe it. Judge Cooper steps in.

I’m glad to hear that, Mrs. Altmann. But from now on, would you mind speaking only when you are asked? There are certain procedures which need to be adhered to in a court-room. And Maria smiles apologetically. Randy is still reeling.  87 INT. COURTROOM, THE DISTRICT COURT. DAY. And now Randy is giving his response.

Your Honour, Mr.Gould is right to point out that the FSIA was enacted in 1976 but he is mistaken in his theory that it can not be applied retroactively. He lifts some documents; hands them to a COURT MARSHALL. Court Marshall hands them over to Judge Cooper, who scans them. Meanwhile, Randy passes copies of them to the opposition.
Despite the fact that actions accruing before 1976 are rarer, they very much exist, these are just three examples of them.
Thank you, Mr. Schoenberg, I’m sure these will prove to be a riveting read. Let’s adjourn for ten minutes. And Randy smiles at her sarcasm.

head_text.subj: INT. COURTROOM, THE DISTRICT COURT. DAY

text: Gould again, still confident but a little less so.

This is a domestic matter for Austria. Anything else would be a violation of its national sovereignty. After all, there is a forum available for Mrs. Altmann to pursue her case in Austria without resorting to the use of American courts and American tax-payer’s money.

head_text.subj: INT. COURTROOM, THE DISTRICT COURT. DAY

text: Randy is becoming more confident as he goes on.

Your Honour, I applaud Mr. Gould’s concern for the American tax-payer but taking the defendant to court in Austria would require her to be a multi-milionairess. It is not an option. In a matter of fact your Honour, we have exhausted all other options. If we hadn’t we wouldn't be standing before you today.  88 INT. COURTROOM, THE DISTRICT COURT. DAY. And JUDGE COOPER gives her verdict from the bench.

The plaintiff has adequately proved that the FSIA can apply to pre 1976 events. Also, due to prohibitive costs, this Court has decided that Austria provides an inadequate forum for resolution of plaintiff's claims.
Your Honour..
Defendant’s Motion to dismiss is denied.
All rise. People stand as Judge Cooper exits. Randy whispers to Mar
First hurdle down.
I’ve always thought there should be more women judges. INT. COURTROOM, THE DISTRICT COURT. DAY. Randy approaches Toman as he is about to leave the courtr
Dr. Toman.
Congratulations Mr. Schoenberg. An unexpected outcome which no doubt has delighted you.
You’re a busy man who can’t be that keen on spending the good part of his life traipsing through the U.S. Court system. I would urge you to consider mediation.
There will be no mediation Mr. Schoenberg. You have been exceptionally lucky today, that is all. Good-day to you. Maria, who’s been over-hearing the conversation, waves at Toman.

Enjoy Disneyland!  89 And Toman walks away. INT. MARIA’S LIVING ROOM. DAY. Maria is having her hair done at home. EIGHT MONTHS have passed and she is looking a little more frail. A HAIRDRES a middle aged woman, has just finished and is showing her back of her head with a portable mirror.
Appeal, appeal, appeal. The Austrians keep appealing and they’re denied every time.
They don’t give up easily, that much you have in common.
So now we're going all the way to the Supreme Court. Which is why I need you to make me look like a million dollars. The phone rings and she leans over and answers it.

Hello? Randy, what’s happened to you? I’m getting my hair done Washington style. EXT. THE SCHOENBERGS’ GARDEN. DAY. Randy is on the wireless phone in the garden when Pam approaches him. She is very noticeably pregnant.
Okay, that’s fine, so I’ll see you at the airport. And he switches it off. She’s picked up that he’s trouble something.
What’s wrong?
I chickened out. I don’t have the heart to tell her.
Tell her what?
Our own Government has filed a brief in Austria’s favour. Can you believe that?
Why?  90
The Iraq war.
They need as many friends as they can get?
They don’t want to start antagonising their allies.
So now you’re fighting the Americans as well...

Feels like I’m fighting the whole damn world. And Pam looks at him. Something in her can’t help admirin him. And that same thing starts to change her. She doesn’ want to be one of the people he’s fighting anymore.

My money’s on you. EXT. BURTON WAY, L.A. DAY. In the afternoon sunshine, Maria crosses the street on he way to The Four Seasons Hotel. INT. FOUR SEASONS HOTEL CAFE. DAY. Maria is in the cafe of The Four Seasons being walked to table by a waitress. At the table sits RONALD LAUDER, a m who exudes elegance and wealth. He stands.
Mrs. Altmann, I’m Ronald Lauder.

The son of Estee. I’ve always loved your mother’s cosmetics. Her lip- stick is my favourite. INT. FOUR SEASONS HOTEL CAFE. DAY. A few minutes later. Maria and Lauder are having tea, Lau talking with focussed intensity.
The art works stolen by the Nazis are the last prisoners of World War Two. And Adele is their queen.
My aunt would be flattered.  91
I was a young man when I first saw the portrait and I instantly fell in love.
She has that effect on people.
Which is why I want her for the Neve Galerie in New York. I will put my offer in writing but have no doubt, it will be substantial.
We are jumping the gun a little, Mr. Lauder.
One needs to do what one can to make a favourable outcome as likely as possible . Which brings me to young Mr. Schoenberg. He’s been a formidable ally.
And continues to be one.
But he’s not cut out for the Supreme Court Mrs. Altmann. A little like sending a school-boy onto the front line.
You think so?

I’m willing to pay for you to have the finest representation from this point on. The man I have in mind is to art restitution what Einstein is to relativity. He’s done his homework on your case and I’m ready to parachute him in. Can I ask him to call you?
You can ask him to take a hike. Lauder is flummoxed.

I’m sticking with my school-boy, Mr. Lauder. And that’s final. INT. THE SCHOENBERG’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. Randy is lying in bed surrounded by pages and pages of wo documents, rehearsing for his imminent appearance at the Supreme Court. He practices out loud.  92
Your Honours, this repeated attempt by the defence to have the case dismissed.. Pam appears at the door in her nightie. Considering what she’s about to say, her attitude is quite relaxed.
Randy. We need to drop Dora off at your mother’s and get to the hospital.
You think I should go deeper with the voice?
Honey. My water broke. He looks at her, taking on what she’s just said. In shock jumps up.
Okay. Stay calm, stay calm. But she is calm, he’s the one freaking out as he hurriedl dresses. Pam calmly takes an overnight bag out, places it the bed, and starts putting clothes into it.
Randy, I’m fine.
You’re having a baby.
I’m aware of that.
I‘1l get the car. Do you need to sit? Do you need a glass of water?
Randy, relax.. I’ve done this before, I’1ll be okay. She takes some of his ties out, throws them on the bed.
Which tie are you going to wear to the Supreme Court?
Are you sure that’s important right now? She chucks him a slightly old-fashioned green one.
Wear the one your Dad got you for good luck. With the blue shirt.  93 And then she sits on the bed, signals for him to do sit n to her. He does.
You need to take me to the hospital and then you need to go to Washington. You need to do it for all of us.
Are you sure that’s what you want?

Listen to me. I got it wrong. Whatever I said, I want you to know I’m with you now. And if it doesn’t work out, we’ll manage. Either way, we'll be okay. You’re doing the right thing, and I love you. She touches his face, smiles warmly. And he knows that sh now understands something of why he had to take on the ca Then, suddenly, movement. She flinches, looks down.
He’s getting twitchy.

We need to go. I’m not good at the whole midwife thing. EXT. WASHINGTON. DAY. Washington in the winter sun: Capitol Hill, the White Hou The Supreme Court. INT. WASHINGTON HOTEL. DAY. Maria is sitting on the edge of the bed coaching Randy wh stands before her.
Do it again without the arms. Randy starts speaking with his arms glued to his side.
Mr Chief Justice and may it please the Court..
Now you look like a pillar.
This is great for my confidence.
Move them but not like before. Somewhere between a windmill and a pillar.  94
Maria, this really isn’t helping. I need to go through the briefs.
Alright, I’1l leave you alone now. She gets up and makes her way towards the door. Then turn him.
Speak from the heart, Randy, and you'll be fine.

Will I? And his question hovers in the air. Suddenly, they’re bot aware that they might be well out of their depth. EXT. THE SUPREME COURT. DAY. In the morning sunshine, the Supreme Court stands proud. INT. THE SUPREME COURT. DAY. And in the Court, everybody is settling down for the sess to begin. Randy on the one side with Maria, Gould, Toman FRANKS (representing the US Government) on the other. Mar leans over to Randy again, offers him a cough-sweet.
Have a cough drop. They are cherry flavoured. Randy takes it but he is a nervous wreck as he shuffles through his documents. Maria leans further in, puts her h on his arm.

You know, my dear, even if we go no further, we made it to the Supreme Court. Who'd have thought it? A little Austrian girl like me... INT. ELLIS ISLAND DETENTION WARD. DAY. 1938. On a hot July day, with a view of New York seen through a window, a few poorly dressed people mill around their bun in a dormitory of a tenement for newly-arrived refugees. man is tuning an accordion, some children are looking at comic book, a woman sits on the edge of her bed, staring ahead. In amongst them, lying on a bunk, are Maria and Fritz. They sit on the bed with brochures promoting California spread out before them. They are sharing a bot of cheap wine, and trying to stay cheerful in this new, unknown country.  95
Can you please show me the way to the wash-room, sir?
Now say it again, but with an American accent. If you say it like that, nobody will understand you.
You can talk! You sound like a silly Frankfurter!
I am aman, not a sausage! Just then, as they giggle, the door opens and a WARDEN wa in, someone who works at the tenement. He is holding a telegram.
Maria Altmann! Which one of you is Maria Altmann?

I am! Maria jumps off the bed and runs up to the man, who hands the telegram, then walks out a it, reads it. And we know that has suddenly shaken her to the the bunk, almost falling on to puts his hand on hers.
What is it?
It’s from my sister. She's waiting for us in California. But she’s had news from Vienna.
Your parents? little gruffly. Maria opens whatever it is she is reading, very core. She walks back to it, as her legs buckle. Fritz
Was ist los? YOUNG MARIA (CONT’D) Es ist von meiner schwester. Sie wartet auf uns in Kalifornien. Aber sie hat Nachrichten aus Wien.
Deine Eltern? She collapses into his arms, and weeps. INT. THE SUPREME COURT. DAY. The session has begun. CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST speaks - h an intimidating, authoritative presence.  96
We'll hear argument next in 03-13, the Republic of Austria v. Maria Altmann. Mr.Gould.
Mr Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: I’ll keep my argument succinct sir: this is a domestic matter for Austria. It has no place in the American Courts.
Mr Franks, representing the United States Government, your opening statement please. Franks is talking now and his age and experience emanate his every pore.
Mr Chief Justice, if this law were to be applied retroactively it could open claims brought against a number of foreign states which would further complicate our international relations.
Give me an example.
Well there are currently cases pending against countries such as Japan and France with which..
So what you’re saying is that Mrs. Altmann shouldn’t try and reclaim her paintings because it might affect our relations with Japan?
That could be a possible outcome Your Honour.

Mrs. Altmann, it seems that if your case goes forward world diplomacy will collapse and you will be solely responsible. Subdued laughter from the audience. INT. THE SUPREME COURT. DAY. Randy stands for his big moment. He is very nervous, very stiff.  97

Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court: We believe that applying the FSIA is not impermissibly retroactive. Chief Justice Rehnquist starts to ask him a question. Ran is like a bunny in the headlights of a car.
Why isn’t it just as easy to say that it does operate retroactively because the question is when should it exercise jurisdiction for a particular purpose? Randy is completely lost.
I’m sorry. I didn’t understand the question. The embarrassment is palpable. Maria looks at the floor. Toman can’t help but let out a little smirk.

I don’t think I did, either. And the tension is burst. Everyone laughs and Randy sighs with relief. CJ REHNQUIST (CONT’D) Did anyone? And more laughter. INT. THE SUPREME COURT. DAY. We watch him grow in confidence and stature with every wo

We're very sensitive to the Government’s concerns, Mr Chief Justice, the can of worms argument. But each country is different and poses different conditions. Unlike say Cuba, in Austria’s case there's a treaty so there’s no dispute as to what type of law could apply. We recommend opening the can but extracting our one little worm with a pair of tweezers. And then closing it shut again. And laughter from the audience.
The defendants have continuously tried to frustrate our attempts, raising every possible objection and threatening an Armageddon in international relations. (MORE)

But let’s put things into perspective here: this is a case about one woman wanting back what is rightfully hers. Mrs. Altmann came to America as a young woman in search of peace. Let’s give her justice too. Maria looks up at Randy and her eyes are beaming with pri INT. AN ANTEROOM, THE SUPREME COURT. DAY. In a room just outside the courtroom, Maria and Randy fin themselves in the middle of a media scrum. A REPORTER pla a mike under Maria.
Mrs. Altmann were you surprised that the U.S. Government supported the Austrians in trying to get the case dismissed?
Everybody wants me to hurry up and die, why not the Americans as well? The journalists laugh. Randy is standing at the side when is approached by another COURT REPORTER.
David Pike, Court Reporter. You were impressive in there, no doubt.
Why, thank you. Randy Schoenberg. He gives him his card.
Takes about three months for the verdict to come though. But there’s no way you’re gonna win.
Okay.
I’ve been doing this job for thirty- four years and I’m always right. It’s in their body language.
Well, thank you very much. That’s a cheerful way to end the day.

No problem. And he ambles off leaving Randy dumb-struck to digest wha he’s just heard.  99 INT. THE SCHOENBERG'S BEDROOM. DAY. Randy rushes into the bedroom with a ridiculously large bouquet of flowers. And then he sees them: Pam, in bed, holding their new baby son.
Hey. Say hi to your son.

Hi Nathan. And he is overwhelmed. EXT. THE SCHOENBERGS’ GARDEN. DAY. Superimposed caption: THREE MONTHS LATER. Maria, Pam and Randy are sitting on the lawn - Pam is hol Nathan in her arms while Dora runs laughing around Maria. Dora is looking older than when we last saw her, she’s a toddler.
She takes after her father. Can’t sit still for a moment!
Are you calling me hyper-active?
Like you have spiders crawling in your underwear all the time. Randy keeps looking at his watch.
Sweetie, will you stop looking at your watch every two minutes?
You’re making us all nervous.

They said we should hear by noon. The phone rings. Randy runs indoors to answer it. Maria a Pam look at each other and smile at the speed with which run into the house. INT. THE SCHOENBERGS’ KITCHEN. DAY. He answers the phone. Through the window we can see Pam a Maria playing with the kids, though obviously on tenterho themselves.
Hello?  EXT. THE SCHOENBERGS’ GARDEN. DAY. 100 Randy comes out, walks up to where Maria and Pam are sitt He looks downcast, as if the news is bad.
I told you not to get excited but you didn’t listen to me.
Bad news I’m afraid. You can’t give up yet. The fight goes on.
What are you talking about?
The Supreme Court has ruled in our favour. We can take the Austrians to trial, Maria. Pam jumps up and hugs him.
Oh my God, Randy, you did it! Maria too stands up, walks to him, takes his face in her hands.

From the first moment I saw you, I knew you were the right man for the job! That’s why I ignored all the terrible bits. And she plants a big smacker on his cheek. Randy smiles b is holding back a little bit; almost as if he can’t quite allow himself to feel the joy of the moment. EXT. THE SCHOENBERGS’ DRIVEWAY . DAY. And in the evening light, Randy and Pam are waving at Mar as she is driven away in a taxi. Randy is holding Nathan, is holding Dora. But Pam has picked something up in Randy behaviour.
Are you okay? I thought this was the outcome you wanted.
Just something I've been thinking over that kind of puts a damper on the celebrations. She looks at him, not understanding.
Sure, we can take them to court. But they’1l find other ways to stretch it out. Could take a few more years. She might not live to see the outcome. (MORE)
And we can’t afford it. Four more months and the bailiff’s at the door.
We’ve come so far, there’s no way we can stop now. I’m frightened, but I’m with you. And he kisses her - in acknowledgement of how far she’s travelled. And then, in that moment, an idea comes to him
There’s only one more thing we could try. And then, Pam too, well-versed in the case, gets it.

Mediation. INT. BOARDROOM. DAY. In a slick board-room in Los Angeles, Randy and Maria sit the one side of the table, Toman on the other. And betwee them sits Professor DIETER BINDER, an elderly Austrian historian who is the mediator.
Welcome.
Funny how things turn out in the end.
We really want to avoid going to trial here in America.
You’ve done an effective job proving that Dr. Toman.
So we’re happy to consider other options. Austria is all ears.
How very refreshing.
Despite my protestations, my client is prepared to meet you half way.
As a gesture of reconciliation I am willing to allow the paintings to remain in the Belvedere. All you have to do is admit that you took them illegally.  102
And then come to an agreement with us on the question of compensation.
I’m afraid we’re not budging, and that is final. We will not be paying for something we believe is ours and we will fight you to the death before we concede on this. Another impasse. Binder steps in.
I’m assuming you all want this to be over so let’s study the other options we have. Randy talks but he is already nervous at how his next wor will be taken my Maria.
Arbitration in Vienna.
Randy!
We chose one of the arbitrators, you choose another. The third is neutral. Toman can hardly believe his ears and has trouble conceal his joy.
Now you are talking sense. This sounds like a reasonable idea. But Maria is in shock.

Randy, can I speak to you in private for a moment? And from her tone, Randy knows she’s having none of it. INT. CORRIDOR OUTSIDE THE BOARDROOM. DAY. Maria and Randy are standing outside the boardroom. Throu the glass wall we can see Toman and Binder. Maria is fier and adamant. Randy was prepared for this and is doing his best to reassure her.
Have you lost your mind?
I want to see you getting your paintings back Maria. I'd like you to get them before..  103
Before, I die is what you mean.
Well, frankly, yes.
And you're crazy enough to think that some arbitration in Vienna will vote in our favour?
I honestly don’t think we have a choice.
But that means we have to go back to Austria. Randy starts to lose his patience with her.
Maria. Listen to me. I can’t sit here arguing with you, okay? I’m doing what I think is best. You need to just be quiet for once, and trust me.

No, Randy, I will not be quiet! I’m sorry. Enough is enough. And she’s already opened the door to the boardroom. INT. BOARDROOM. DAY. She strides up to where her handbag is, picks it up, turn Toman and speaks, dignified and strident in equal measure

Congratulations, Dr. Toman. Your tactics have succeeded. I am not playing this game anymore. Goodbye, gentlemen. And she sweeps out of the boardroom, leaving Binder speechless. Toman can’t help but release a tiny look of satisfaction. INT. CORRIDOR OUTSIDE THE BOARDROOM. DAY. And she sweeps by Randy, not stopping for a second. EXT. MARIA’S FRONT YARD. DAY. Randy drives up to Maria’s bungalow, pulls over, gets out and runs towards the front door. He is worked up, fuming. rings the doorbell and a couple of seconds later, Maria o the door but doesn’t let him in.  104
Nice one, Maria. Thank you.
I’m not in the mood, I don’t want to talk to you.

The feeling is mutual but we don’t have the choice right now. She tries to close the door, he puts his foot in it and blocks it. INT. MARIA’S HALLWAY. DAY. Exasperated, Maria opens the door, walks into the hallway Randy follows her into the house. She turns on him. And w she speaks it is with a quiet steel in her voice. She’s m her mind up.
It’s over, Randy! We made a mistake.
What’s over? What are you saying?
I’m saying that we have to accept defeat and return to what’s left of our lives.
Are you insane?

I’m saying that I’m tired and that they can keep the paintings. I’m saying Randy, that as of this moment, I no longer need your services. Randy can not believe what he’s hearing. And when he erup Maria is not prepared for the full force of it.

Are you kidding me? I have given everything I have! I am HALF A MILLION DOLLARS in debt and my wife and I are..my children, everything I fucking care about in this world....and you have the nerve..everything I’ve done I’ve done to get those goddamn paintings back for you...I wish you’d never asked me.. and you have the nerve to come to me and say that it’s all over! And he stops and Maria is standing there, looking at him, shaken by his rage. And, softening, he speaks quietly.  105
We've come so far...just hang in there.

The Austrians will never let go. And I won't be humiliated again. Go back to Vienna if you have to. But this time I’m not coming back with you. You’re on your own Randy. And the two of them stand silently opposite each other in hallway of her small house, shaken by their emotions. EXT. VIENNA. NIGHT. Montage of Vienna at night. EXT. VIENNA STREET. NIGHT. Randy and Hubertus are walking down a street in the old p of town.

The man you chose for the arbitration panel is a safe bet.. but I’m a little worried about the other two, I can’t lie. The one chosen by the Austrian State is a strict traditionalist. I can’t see him deciding in your favour. And as for the third..well,it’s a gamble.
Here’s hoping.

But I never thought you’d come back. And personally, I need to be honest - I don’t think it’s the right decision. You are betting on Austria having changed. And Hubertus’ eyes suggest that it might be a bet too far They pass by a small concert hall. A poster catches Randy eye: there’s an Arnold Schoenberg concert starting in twe minutes. He looks at Hubertus and they smile at the coincidence. Randy checks his watch and runs to the box office, gives his credit card to the female BOX OFFICE EMPLOYEE, who takes it.
Two tickets, please.
It starts in two minutes. And then she notices the name on the card. BOX OFFICE EMPLOYEE (CONT’D) You have the same name as the composer.  106 Hubertus looks at Randy and they smile to each other.

What a coincidence. INT. CONCERT HALL. NIGHT. Randy and Hubertus sit in the darkened concert hall. Rand listens proudly to his grandfather’s music, watching the orchestra playing and the crowd appreciating it. And something is inspired in him. INT. THE ARBITRATION ROOM. DAY. The arbitration. A large room in a Government building in Vienna. At a long table sit the three arbitrators. In the room there is also a sizeable audience which includes Hubertus, Elizabeth Gehrer, Wran and Toman. Randy stands the panel. One of the arbitrators stands.

The Austrian Government has provided its case in writing for our perusal. Mr. Schoenberg, you too were offered the opportunity to do so but you have opted to present the introductory points of your argument orally as well, is that correct?
I have, yes.
The floor is yours.

Thank you sir. Randy stands in the centre of the room and it feels like whole of Austria is his audience. He clears his throat, t a deep breath but looks uncertain - almost as if he can’t it. He begins but his tone lacks confidence, it wavers.

Ladies and gentlemen, I’m happy to be standing before you today for two reasons. Firstly, like my opponents in this case I always believed that this was a domestic matter for Austria that needed to be decided within her borders. Suddenly he’s interrupted: a door opens at the back of th room. His eyes are drawn to it. It’s Maria. She’s come af all. She walks up to the front of the room and sits. Rand comes to her, leans in, and they whisper to each other.
I wasn't expecting to see you here.  107

The first time I came back for myself. This time I came back for you. Now, stand up straight. He looks at her, takes strength from her words, straighte up, and resumes his opening speech - she has moved and inspired him. He takes a deep breath and he looks two inc taller. And the speech is now driven by a new confidence.
And the second reason I’m happy to be in Vienna today is because my client Mrs. Altmann and I are both Austrians. Some of the audience seem surprised but Maria knows what means.

Oh, don’t get me wrong, we’re very much Americans too. But our families and the roots we share are situated in the culture of this very city. INT. CONCERT HALL, VIENNA. NIGHT. And we see a flashback to the night before and Randy observing the audience as they listen to his grandfather' music INT. KLIMT’S STUDIO. DAY. And now we see Adele being painted by Klimt once more, as puts the final touches to the great painting.

And somewhere, in the heart of this world, stands the woman whose portrait both sides are fighting for. Adele Bloch-Bauer. INT. THE ARBITRATION ROOM. DAY. Randy in full flow now, the confident, experienced lawyer has become.

During my visits to this country I have discerned that there are two Austrias: the one that opposes restitution to the victims of Nazism, and another that recognises the injustice committed against Austria’s Jewish population and seeks to rectify it. We watch Dr Toman, Elizabeth Gehrer and Rudolf Wran responding to what he is saying and then we land on Huber the two Austrias.  108

As I hope I demonstrate in my written arguments, the law favours restitution. And now, during these next few scenes we watch a flashing montage of the journey of the painting and the way it end up in the Belvedere -- EXT. VIENNA. DAY. The Anchluss: The Viennese crowds greet the Nazis in celebration, women throwing flowers to welcome them.

A string of events and misdeeds point to the incontestible fact that the paintings in question reached the Belvedere Gallery and remained there for over half a century in a manner that was both dishonest and illegal. And that Adele’s will itself was not legally binding. INT. LIVING ROOM ELIZABETHSTRASSE. DAY. The auction at Elizabethstrasse. EXT. ELIZABETHSTRASSE. DAY. The painting of Adele being loaded onto a truck. INT. THE BELVEDERE. DAY. And the painting coming to hang on the wall of the Belved under Grimshitz’s supervision. INT. THE ARBITRATION ROOM. DAY. And as Randy reaches the conclusion he slows his tempo a little to make sure these last few words really land.

In its own way Ladies and Gentlemen this is a moment of history, a moment in which the past is asking something of the present. Many years ago, (in this very city,) just beyond these walls, terrible things happened. People dehumanised other people - they persecuted them, sent many to their deaths, and decimated whole families breaking them apart forever. And they stole from them - properties, livelihoods and the objects that were most precious to them. (MORE )

Amongst those people were the Bloch- Bauers, the family of a very dear friend of mine. So now I am asking you - as Austrians - as human beings - to recognise that wrong. (Not just for Maria Altmann but for Austria.) I am asking you today to look at the past, as I have, and to restore what has been taken away. And his eyes meet Maria’s. And by articulating these last words, he understands that he too, in some profound way, been restored. And it is clear that his words have resona with his audience, especially on the faces of Toman and W EXT. THE PRATER PARK. DAY. Maria, Randy and Hubertus are walking in the shade of the Ferris Wheel. Randy is checking his phone.
They said they should announce the verdict by four.
One thing is for sure. This country is about to decide what it really is. They approach a bench and sit down on it. HUBERTUS (CONT’D) When I was a child, my father used to bring me here on Sundays.
For waffles and ice-cream, eh?

And a ride on the ferris wheel. And he knows that now is the moment to confide; their friendship has earned it. HUBERTUS (CONT’D) He was an impressive man, tall and domineering with his hair always combed back. Handsome, I suppose. As a small boy I looked up to him, worshipped him.
